thread.title: Questions that won’t be asked in the GOP debate | Jon Talton
thread.title_full: Questions that won’t be asked in the GOP debate | Jon Talton | The Seattle Times

author: Jon Talton
title: Questions that won’t be asked in the GOP debate | Jon Talton
text:
Ten Republican presidential candidates will gather in Cleveland tonight for a prime-time debate on Fox. Here are some questions I bet won’t be asked — and that’s too bad.
1. Mr. Trump, you have never held elective office and have no foreign-policy experience. Many of your business ventures have landed in bankruptcy court. What qualifies you to be here?
2. (to all) Presidents George W. Bush and Obama faced the greatest economic crisis since the Great Depression. What did they do right and not so well in addressing it? How would you address such a crisis?
3. President Obama’s Justice Department did not bring criminal charges against the CEOs of the institutions most responsible for the financial collapse. Do you agree with this or would you have sought criminal prosecutions?
Most Read Stories ESPN video: Percy Harvin opens up about what went wrong in Seattle Amazon angst: from traffic to housing, we’re all worked up It’s election time. Will Howard Schultz run for president? Godden trailing; 5 incumbents move on for City Council Seahawks safety Kam Chancellor still holding out with no end in sight 4. Would you stop the “revolving door” between regulatory agencies and the industries they regulate, where officials can move to highly-paid jobs in the private sector in the very companies they were charged with overseeing?
5. Do you agree with the Citizens United decision, which conferred “personhood rights” on corporations, allowing them to give unlimited political donations?
6. Would you break up the so-called Too Big to Fail Banks that were at the center of the financial crisis and instate a new Glass-Steagall Act? If not, why not?
7. The military procurement process is broken, with the troubled and massively expensive F-35 Joint Strike Fighter as the most glaring example. How would you fix this problem?
8. American companies that enjoy the full protection and benefits of operating in the United States are stashing $2.1 trillion in profits overseas to avoid taxes. Considering President Bush’s “tax holiday” was a failure, how would you address this tax dodging?
9. The United States suffers from the greatest income inequality since at least the eve of the Great Depression. It is worse than virtually any other advanced country. Studies show it holds back growth. What is government’s role in addressing this and what policies would you pursue?
10. Do you believe climate change is largely the result of human activity, as do 97 percent of the scientists who actually study climate. If not, why not? If so, what policies would you pursue to keep carbon out of the atmosphere?
Happy viewing.
Today’s Econ Haiku:
Will Trump steal the show?
As long as the wind don’t blow
Combover crisis
I invite you to follow me on Twitter @jontalton
